bioghist.p: In 1982, the Center for the History of Chemistry (CHOC) was launched as a pilot project of the University of Pennsylvania and the American Chemical Society (ACS). In 1987 CHOC was incorporated as a not-for-profit organization, now named the National Foundation for the History of Chemistry, by joint action of the ACS and AIChE, the Center's third sponsor. In 1992 the Chemical Heritage Foundation (CHF) assumed its present name to better reflect the interdisciplinary nature of the sciences and industries it serves and the widening public scope of its activities.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records of the Chemical Heritage Foundation's historical services and archives projects. These records pertain primarily to CHF's Biomolecular Sciences Initiative (BIMOSI) -- a project designed to document contemporary history of the life sciences by conducting oral histories with molecular biologists, coordinating archival planning, exploring historical questions raised by the development of molecular biology, and encouraging scientists to donate their papers to appropriate repositories. BIMOSI was funded by grants from the Mellon Foundation and the National Historical Publications and Records Commission. Its particular focus was on documenting the Human Genome Project. BIMOSI records (1985-1996) include: correspondence to scientists and institutions urging participation, information on document preservation strategies, articles and reprints on archives and archival methods, lists of scientists in molecular biology, notes from internal meetings on the project, including the Archival Advisory Committee, grant proposals and progress reports. The collection also includes papers (1998-2000) of Leo Slater. Slater is an historian of science who was CHF's Director of Historical Services. These materials include: memos, agendas and other records from meetings revolving around different historical projects, many of them undertaken with divisions of the American Chemical Society.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
